body.p: Bābā Rukn al-Dīn Shīrāzī, Mausoleum, the mausoleum and takiyya of Bābā Rukn al-Dīn Shīrāzī (q.v.) is an Īlkhānid structure located in the Takht-i Fūlād district of Iṣfahān (see Fig. 3). The earliest reference to this building in historical sources relates to its renovation during the Ṣafawid period by order of Shāh ʿAbbās I (r. 995–1038/1587–1629) (see Jābirī Anṣārī, 326). This information, together with the style of its structure, suggest that the mausoleum was first built in the Īlkhānid period, i.e. soon after Bābā Rukn al-Dīn al-Shīrāzī’s death in 769/1368. Some sources likewise indicate that he was buried in the grounds of the takiyya dedicated to his memory—which points to the existence of the takiyya during his life-time (Mahdawī, 153). Notwithstanding the inscription over the mausoleum’s entrance īwān, which refers to the decree by Shāh ʿAbbās and to the date of the completion of construction being 1039/1630 (i.e. during the reign of Shāh Ṣafī, r. 1038–1052/1629–1642) (see Hunarfar, 494; cf. Humāʾī, vi), the dome is clearly of Īlkhānid style, a feature that many scholars have acknowledged (Humāʾī, ii; Nīkzād, ‘Āthār’, 27). A comparison of this mausoleum with that of Bābā Qāsim (q.v.), built in Iṣfahān in 741/1340 (see Godard, 2(1)/38–39), reveals many similarities that further support the earlier date for the initial construction of Bābā Rukn al-Dīn’s mausoleum.

The tomb of this renowned Sufi is situated on the southern bank of the Zāyandah-rūd in the Takht-i Fūlād cemetery, and is considered one of the more important of the many historic tombs there. Even in the post-Ṣafawid period, Bābā Rukn al-Dīn had such renown that the cemetery was known by his name; indeed the Khʷājū Bridge, which is on the way to the shrine, came to be known by the same name as well (Mahdawī, 153).

According to Pīrniyā (pp. 143, 147), the mausoleum with its conical dome was built in the ‘Rāzī’ style—a combination of Khurāsānī and Tabrīzī elements. The base of the dome is pentagonal, rising into a pyramid, one side of which bears an inscription.
The axis of the building is exactly aligned with the qibla (towards Mecca). The drum of the dome (sāqah) is decagonal. The harmonious correspondence of all the dimensions and details of the building testifies to the devotion applied to its planning and construction (Hunarfar, 494; Godard, 1(1)/127–128). Pope refers to the existence of a mausoleum with a conical dome in the Takht-i Fūlād cemetery, without identifying it by name (2/1217).

The building boasts five identical īwāns which underpin the circumference of the dome, one of which houses Bābā Rukn al-Dīn’s tomb. The tomb itself is covered by a large marble slab some 2 m long and 1.16 m wide. Another, upright, stone tablet bearing an inscription in fine thulth script is installed at the head of the tomb (for a full transcription, see ‘Āthār-i bāstān’, 43). The inscription over the front entrance of the mausoleum is in a white thulth script on an azure tile background (Hunarfar, 494–495). According to Humāʾī (pp. iv–v), the words kalb al-fuqarāʾ (dog of the poor men) which appear on the damaged inscription should in fact read katabahu al-faqīr (penned by the humble man) (cf. Hunarfar, 495).

The original ceiling tilework featured designs in blue, white and black on a turquoise background (Godard, 2(1)/125, 127), but none of these can be seen today. The only tilework that remains is that of a fine inscription over the entrance antechamber (pīsh-khʷān), together with that on four of the ten sides of the pyramid structure of the dome (Hunarfar, 494–495).

Renovations to the structure were first carried out under Shāh ʿAbbās I and completed at the beginning of the reign of Shāh Ṣafī. Further renovations were undertaken by the Ṣafawid Shāh Sulṭān Ḥusayn (r. 1105–1135/1694–1722), as evidenced by an inscription containing a verse with the date 1112/1701; this inscription, in a fine nastaʿlīq, is found on a plasterwork wall in one of the chambers known as the chillah-khānah, or solitary cell, located adjacent to the tomb (see Humāʾī, vi).

According to another nastaʿlīq inscription, a certain Mīrzā Muḥammad Naṣīr Bāyazīdī Basṭāmī undertook further renovations of the building in 1200/1786. This inscription which is carved on a stone tablet on the western wall of the entrance īwān, is situated just below the Shāh ʿAbbās inscription. Mīrzā Muḥammad’s renovations were continued by both Ḥājj Mīrzā Sulaymān Khān Rukn al-Mulk Shīrāzī (d. 1331/1913), who was for a while deputy governor of Iṣfahān, and Chirāgh ʿAlī Khān Sirāj al-Mulk during the period of his governorship of Iṣfahān in 1267–1271/1851–1855 (Humāʾī, vii–viii; Hunarfar, 499–500). In 1950, repairs to the mausoleum were undertaken by the Iranian Archaeological Organisation (Nīkzād, Fihrist, 195; see also Mishkʷātī, 53).
